quote: Society in every state is a blessing, but government even in its best state is but a necessary evil;
desc: This quote, from the first page of Common Sense, lays out Paine's general conception of government. His general view that government is "but a necessary evil" forms an intellectual backdrop against which it is easier to call for an outright rebellion against the British government.

quote: To say, they will never attempt it again is idle and visionary, we thought so at the repeal of the s
desc: This quote comes from the third section of Common Sense, in which Paine considers the details of America's relationship with Britain. Here, he argues that the British simply cannot be trusted to deal fairly with the colonies. Paine points out that the British have repeatedly imposed unfair taxes, and even after they repealed them, as with the stamp-act, later imposed new ones.
